BE11:21am

Crest has issued another profit warning this morning, the FD has stood down and Steve Stone (former CEO, current Chairman) is coming back in an operational role to implement a new strategy of prioritizing cash returns over growth. Profit before tax for FY18 is now expected to be in the range of £170-190m, which is 9%-19% below our estimate of £209m. The ‘ambition’ for FY19 is flat profits y/y (JPMe: £225m). The exact outcome depends on the timing of some individually material transactions. During H2 the group took action to mitigate volume declines, which impacted margin – implying presumably that prices were cut meaningfully – meaning that the margin is now expected to be below the 18% previously guided to. The group is once again saying this is down to a slower London and South East market that it had expected, where sales have not picked up into the traditional autumn selling season. The board has decided to embark on a new strategy of prioritizing cash flows and returns to shareholders. The current dividend is unchanged for this year (at 32p, assuming profits don’t decline further), after which it’s looking to generate cash and maximise shareholder returns. There’s a call at 9am. While there might be scope to be more positive on the medium term strategy today, the material profit downgrade should still be viewed negatively and we still see risk that Crest’s core markets deteriorate further.

FATDAZ I have said this this before re builders and estate agents nut I am stunned by the inability of managements to cope in a 'downturn' in what are classical cyclical businesses.

compared to the sector average of -21%. On last night’s closing price, the shares trade on a CY18 P/NAV of c1x. We base our revised target price of 330p on forecast tangible NAV for FY18. Bid speculation may increase if the shares fall significantly below this level, as we saw with Bovis in 2017. However, we also believe that the ongoing trading backdrop, potential for some modest land write downs and ongoing operational issues will keep a lid on the share price. Hold.

We understand it is difficult for the company to predict the endgame here, as it is evolving fast, but we expect the miss on guidance and lack of visibility will be taken negatively by the market.

MDC is now guiding for modest growth in FY19 (+1.2/+1.4% on GS/ Consensus expectations), but is much more cautious on margins post disappointing 1H19: MDC now expects FY19 EBITDA margin of c.16%, materially below 17.3% expected by both GS and consensus.

Inchcape PLC (INCH:LSE): Last: 545.50, down 71 (-11.52%), High: 616.50, Low: 537.00, Volume: 1.92m
BE11:42am

Good company in a bad place, is the gist.

hornblower shouldn't all housebuilders (and most other companies) prioritise cashflow and returns to shareholders
BE11:42am

Two bad places, in fact. The UK and Australia.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

1. UK new car TIV (total industry volume) fell 20.5% in September to 339k: UK TIV now -7.5% YTD (from -6.3% in H1). Diesel, down 43% in September and 31% YTD, showed modest deterioration from H1. Crucially, UK VW and Audi TIV fell 53-55% in September, now -5% and -10% YTD, respectively; a marked decline on H1 when Audi and VW TIV were flat and +5%, respectively. The shortfall was impacted by a WLTPrelated shortage in new models. Inchcape regarded this as lost revenue. We estimate Audi and VW account for c30% of Inchcape UK new car sales, and now expect a 15% fall in Inchcape H2 new car sales (from -5.0%), with a geared impact on UK trading profit.

BE11:43am

2. Australia new car TIV fell 5.5% in September to 94k: This extends the decline in TIV growth YTD to -1% from +1% in H1. The decline in TIV was led by a fall in demand in New South Wales (NSW) where weakening house prices impacted demand for big ticket purchases. As a result, TIV declined by 9.4% in NSW in September, part of a broader decline that impacted all but one state. While SUV (e.g. Subaru) continues to outperform the market, up 6.2% in September and 8.7% year to date, this trend is also down on H1 at +9.3% and +10.7%, respectively. We expect SUV demand to track a slowdown in market demand in Q4 and moderate Australia FY18e sales/trading profit.

BE11:43am

Plus the fx hit.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

3. Negative FX and the impact of the JPY on FY19e: The JPY has strengthened against the AUD. The resulting impact is an increase in the projected cost of Subaru products exported to Australia. At current spot rates this is expected to impact Australia reported treading profits by GBP20m in FY19e.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

INFLATION!

BE11:46am

Having surprised to the upside in August, at 2.4% y/y CPI inflation for September undershot both our own (2.5% y/y) and the consensus expectation (2.6% y/y) according to today’s release from the ONS.

As we had expected, some of the one-off factors which drove inflation higher in August reversed. In particular, prices in the clothing and footwear category rose less between August and September this year than last. As a result, having made a positive contribution to headline inflation in August, clothing exerted a small negative pull last month.

Elsewhere in the basket, food and drink price rises eased, from 2.5% y/y previously to 1.5% y/y as prices fell m/m between August and September.

Similarly, the contribution from the transport category also fell due to transport fares falling back after sharp rises last month. Within transport, alongside a weaker contribution from air and sea fares, the contribution from motor fuels was less than expected as the pace of pump price increases slowed m/m.

Combined those latter two categories will have shaved 0.2ppts from headline CPI last month.

RPI inflation also eased (to 3.3% y/y from 3.5% previously), though by not as much as CPI widening the wedge between the two in the process. The main contributor to the widening wedge was in the ‘other differences’ category which largely picks up differences in weights.

The surprise to the downside in CPI last month confirms our view that August’s jump higher was a one-off rather than a harbinger of a new upward trend. Today’s release also leaves CPI inflation averaging 2.5% y/y in Q3, i.e. in line with the BoE’s expectations at the time of the August Inflation Report.

So in terms of the MPC’s thinking, today’s inflation data changes little. Inflation is running in line with expectations and above target. The latest GDP data suggest that growth was quite a bit stronger over the summer than expected. The labour market backdrop remains healthy.

All that continues to support the Bank’s ‘gradual and limited’ mantra. However, and at the risk of repeating ourselves, it will require more clarity on Brexit before it will contemplate acting on that guidance.

BE11:46am

THAT'S RBC.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

END-OF-MESSAGE INFLATION

BE11:46am

As for Flybe ....

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Flybe Group PLC (FLYB:LSE): Last: 20.20, down 12 (-37.27%), High: 22.40, Low: 19.05, Volume: 5.90m
BE11:47am

Demand deteriorating in recent weeks.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

And no upturn expected, meaning a pre-tax loss of £22m before nasties.

BE11:48am

Here's Liberum, which is of course the shop broker.

BE11:48am

Flybe has issued a profit warning for the current year citing a weaker outlook for demand in H2, higher fuel and carbon credit costs, and further adverse movements in exchange rates. It is not alone in facing these challenges and we have recently cut our forecasts for easyJet (HOLD, TP 1250p) and Ryanair (BUY, TP €14.50) on fuel headwinds. Management now expects to report for March 2019 an adjusted pre-tax loss of £12m, after the benefit of £10m of provision releases for onerous leases. This implies a £22m pre-tax loss compared with our previous £6m forecast, treating the provision release as an exceptional item.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

The warning on the FY outlook comes despite encouraging trading in H1, the seasonally stronger period. In H1, load factors improved by 8.0pts to 84.0%, with revenue per seat improving by 8%. H1 adjusted PBT is seen similar to last year's £9.4m, excluding onerous lease provision release.

BE11:49am

We have cut our forecasts to reflect management's more cautious outlook and guidance for the current year. We treat the onerous lease provision release as an exceptional item, so our March 2019E forecast of a £22m pre-tax loss is consistent with management's guidance. Given the airline's limited forward visibility on bookings we see the balance of risks to our new estimates as remaining on the downside. The impact on our forecasts for later years reflects the full year effect of the trends highlighted by management, along with less protection from fuel and currency hedging.

BE11:49am

We continue to see turnaround potential at Flybe as it brings capacity into line with potential profitable demand. There remain self-help opportunities to continue to improve revenue per seat, such as new commercial systems, and non-fuel unit costs ought to be brought under better control, helped by cheaper aircraft leases, even with the headwind of seat capacity reductions. However, it is clear that external industry-wide headwinds from weaker demand and a more challenging environment on fuel and FX continue to more than offset management's actions. It is unclear when the balance will become more favourable. We cut our target price to 33p from 43p, based on a calendarised 2018E EV/EBITDAR of 6.3x (previously 6.5x), and retain our HOLD recommendation.
